content.title: Intravascular Lithotripsy for Calcium Modification in PAD

statement.text: Intravascular lithotripsy (IVL) uses sonic pressure waves to fracture intimal and medial calcium, enabling effective angioplasty and stent expansion in severely calcified peripheral arteries.
statement.formal: Mechanism: Sonic pressure waves (1 atm) fracture calcium; Technique: Low-pressure balloon (4 atm) + lithotripsy pulses; Benefit: Enables vessel expansion while preserving soft tissue

explanation.intuition: Heavy calcium in artery walls acts like armor, preventing balloons from stretching the vessel. Lithotripsy is like using sound waves to crack this armor from the inside, allowing the balloon to then expand the artery without damaging soft tissue.
explanation.key_insight: IVL selectively targets calcium while sparing soft tissue, enabling treatment of lesions previously considered unsuitable for endovascular therapy.
explanation.technical_details: Intravascular lithotripsy (Shockwave Medical) integrates lithotripsy emitters into an angioplasty balloon catheter. The balloon is inflated to 4 atm (low pressure) and then emitters deliver sonic pressure waves that propagate through the soft tissue (causing no damage) but fracture rigid calcium (both intimal and medial). Calcium microfractures allow the vessel to expand with subsequent angioplasty or stent deployment. This enables treatment of the 'undilatable' lesion.
common_misconceptions: IVL damages soft tissue - FALSE, sonic waves pass through soft tissue harmlessly
IVL is atherectomy - FALSE, no tissue removal, only calcium modification
High balloon pressures are needed - FALSE, 4 atm is typical
IVL replaces DCB/stenting - FALSE, it's vessel preparation before definitive therapy

physics.wave_propagation: Sonic wave travels through fluid and soft tissue
physics.calcium_interaction: Wave energy creates microfractures in rigid calcium

calcium_fracture.depth: Affects both intimal and medial calcium

femoropopliteal.indication: Severely calcified lesions resistant to standard angioplasty
femoropopliteal.evidence: DISRUPT PAD studies demonstrate safety and efficacy
femoropopliteal.workflow: IVL → DCB or IVL → stent as needed

tibial.consideration: Critical for limb salvage in diabetics

iliac.benefit: Enables stent expansion in calcified iliac

technique.overlap: Reposition and repeat to cover entire lesion
technique.post_treatment: Follow with angioplasty, DCB, or stent

disrupt_pad_ii.significance: Calcified lesions historically have worse outcomes

disrupt_pad_iii.result: Improved procedural success in calcified lesions

general: Enables DCB drug uptake in calcified vessels

definition.@value: Catheter-based technology using sonic pressure waves to fracture arterial calcium, enabling effective endovascular treatment of severely calcified lesions.

presentation: Undilatable lesions resistant to standard angioplasty
treatment: Follow with DCB or stent as indicated

learning_objectives: Explain the mechanism of intravascular lithotripsy
Identify appropriate lesions for IVL treatment
Describe the IVL treatment technique and workflow
Compare IVL to atherectomy for calcium modification
clinical_pearls: IVL fractures calcium without removing tissue - not atherectomy
Only 4 atm inflation pressure needed - low-pressure approach
Addresses BOTH intimal AND medial calcium (atherectomy cannot reach media)
IVL is vessel preparation - follow with DCB or stent
No distal protection required - no embolic debris
